metadata.synopsis: Havkelaag is a member of the Society of Brilliance, who is very interested in proving his theory of Genetic Morality.This dialog only ever plays in case players the gith kid massacre never happens.

37.speaker: Havkelaag
37.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

14.speaker: Havkelaag
14.text: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to the Underdark: the Society of Brilliance.
14.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

130.speaker: Havkelaag
130.text: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
130.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

7.speaker: Player
7.text: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
7.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

58.speaker: Havkelaag
58.text: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.

78.speaker: Havkelaag
78.text: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.

82.speaker: Havkelaag
82.text: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

25.speaker: Havkelaag
25.text: Once the dust is settled on this whole invading army mess outside the walls, I'll find another contractor. Perhaps they will have more success.

34.speaker: Havkelaag
34.text: Was there anything else? I should really get back to my research.

57.speaker: Havkelaag
57.text: Feel free to explore the Lodge. Our knowledge is here for the common good, after all.

4.speaker: Player
4.text: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
4.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

74.speaker: Havkelaag
74.text: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
74.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

122.speaker: Havkelaag
122.text: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
122.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

31.speaker: Player
31.text: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
31.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

76.speaker: Lae'zel
76.text: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
76.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

18.speaker: Player
18.text: What are you going to do with it?
18.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

1.speaker: Player
1.text: What are you going to do with it?
1.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

62.speaker: Havkelaag
62.text: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
62.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

32.speaker: Havkelaag
32.text: You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil.

123.speaker: Havkelaag
123.text: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.

121.speaker: Havkelaag
121.text: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.

41.speaker: Havkelaag
41.text: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
41.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

75.speaker: Havkelaag
75.text: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
75.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

30.speaker: Havkelaag
30.text: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
30.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

132.speaker: Havkelaag
132.text: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
132.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

103.speaker: Player
103.text: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
103.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

100.speaker: Havkelaag
100.text: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside.

115.speaker: Player
115.text: So the child inside will be experimented on?
115.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

117.speaker: Player
117.text: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
117.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

36.speaker: Havkelaag
36.text: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself.

53.speaker: Player
53.text: You assume my people are evil, yet your research is built on sheer superstition.
53.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

33.speaker: Havkelaag
33.text: Enough of your kind have wreaked destruction on this plane for me to be confident in my assertion.
33.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

84.speaker: Havkelaag
84.text: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
84.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

52.speaker: Havkelaag
52.text: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
52.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

124.speaker: Havkelaag
124.text: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
124.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

43.speaker: Havkelaag
43.text: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
43.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

142.speaker: Player
142.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

42.speaker: Havkelaag
42.text: A series of moral imperatives bestowed by the great dragon-deity Bahamut.

102.speaker: Havkelaag
102.text: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.

61.speaker: Player
61.text: So you're planning to torture a child for a year?
61.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

114.speaker: Havkelaag
114.text: The child will be a better individual after my treatment than it ever would have been had it been raised in its natural environment.

96.speaker: Havkelaag
96.text: Any suffering it endures will therefore be worth it, for the child, perhaps for the whole of civilised society.

128.speaker: Havkelaag
128.text: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.

135.speaker: Player
135.text: And what if your experiment fails?

139.speaker: Havkelaag
139.text: If the child remains evil after the experiment is concluded, it will be destroyed. Such is the fate of all used specimens.

27.speaker: Player
27.text: No benefit could justify you inflicting such cruelty.

97.speaker: Havkelaag
97.text: Rigorous experimental methods demand we do not indulge our own emotional responses in the application of discomfort to our subjects.

0.speaker: Havkelaag
0.text: Only by the full, uninhibited application of psionic stimuli will we have a true measure of whether the child's innate evil has been cured.

21.speaker: Havkelaag
21.text: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

24.speaker: Player
24.text: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.

127.speaker: Lae'zel
127.text: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.

55.speaker: Havkelaag
55.text: Wonderful. I'll begin making preliminary notes at once.

63.speaker: Havkelaag
63.text: You've provided me with a fine specimen. I'll be sure to mention your name in the footnotes.

88.speaker: Player
88.text: Tsk'va! To think I trusted you with such a treasure!

56.speaker: Lae'zel
56.text: Tsk'va! To think I trusted you with such a treasure!

77.speaker: Havkelaag
77.text: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.

73.speaker: Havkelaag
73.text: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?

20.speaker: Havkelaag
20.text: That is a shame. I'll have to find another way to procure a specimen. Or some additional funds.

134.speaker: Player
134.text: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

85.speaker: Havkelaag
85.text: Then I will source another subject, and the experiment will be completed without your involvement.

51.speaker: Havkelaag
51.text: Progress may be delayed, but I assure you - it can never be stopped.

86.speaker: Player
86.text: Sounds pointless. Public opinion will hardly be swayed by such a small experiment.

10.speaker: Havkelaag
10.text: Not at first. But if the experiment proves successful, it must be repeated. Only then will we know if the findings are to be trusted.

11.speaker: Player
11.text: An experiment like this will only confirm the surface dwellers' suspicion of us.

106.speaker: Havkelaag
106.text: Of course it won't. If anything, it will do quite the opposite. The academic institutions up here will finally be forced to take us seriously.

69.speaker: Player
69.text: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.

16.speaker: Havkelaag
16.text: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way.

136.speaker: Player
136.text: This experiment is exactly the kind of evil you're trying to disprove.
136.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

111.speaker: Havkelaag
111.text: The pursuit of knowledge is neither evil nor good. Only in the application of such knowledge should one take on any moral imperative.

140.speaker: Player
140.text: You'd better get cracking, then. Here's the egg.
140.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

125.speaker: Player
125.text: Not interested. The egg stays with me.
125.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

109.speaker: Player
109.text: Shka'keth. You will not live to torment the yank within that shell.
109.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

9.speaker: Havkelaag
9.text: The Society have studied your kind's brutality for years. You will not find us so easily intimidated.

2.speaker: Havkelaag
2.text: A githyanki sympathiser? I'd no idea their evil could be passed on. Leave our premises - at once!

101.speaker: Player
101.text: Why follow the dogma of a draconic god?
101.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

133.speaker: Player
133.text: So you, too, follow the teachings of Bahamut. Why him?
133.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

129.speaker: Player
129.text: That kind of indoctrination and time-forced nurture violates the natural order. It invalidates the whole experiment.
129.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

143.speaker: Havkelaag
143.text: I won't bother to argue with you. An arboreal shaman can't be expected to understand the rigorous protocols of theoretical research.

112.speaker: Player
112.text: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
112.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

80.speaker: Havkelaag
80.text: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
80.context: NodeContext: sligthly derisive, smug - he's had this argument in his head before and thinks he's absolutely won it with this point

15.speaker: Player
15.text: Patience does not delay, it simply tempers virtue. Curtails it from excess.

108.speaker: Havkelaag
108.text: A cautious, hesitant instinct. One I am afraid we do not have time for.

45.speaker: Player
45.text: By your words, any virtue delaying patience would itself be unvirtuous.

26.speaker: Havkelaag
26.text: And therein lies your fault: you would have us argue in circles until the egg hatches naturally. Time we do not have.

46.speaker: Player
46.text: Perhaps not. Patience is important, but cannot impede the other virtues.

90.speaker: Havkelaag
90.text: Then we are in accord - the time for action is now.

94.speaker: Player
94.text: A worthwhile aspiration. You're welcome to the egg.

29.speaker: Player
29.text: No, thanks. I've grown quite attached to it.

113.speaker: Havkelaag
113.text: I'd no idea your kind were capable of showing such parental instincts.

48.speaker: Havkelaag
48.text: I assure you, forming any emotional attachment to the gith spawn is quite pointless. It will show you no such affection in return.

47.speaker: Havkelaag
47.text: Should you grow tired of your responsibilities, do bring the egg to me. I'll gladly take it off your hands.

119.speaker: Player
119.text: I'd like to become a member.
119.context: NodeContext: Defensive, has heard this accusation before

83.speaker: Havkelaag
83.text: A most intelligent impulse, but I'm afraid it simply isn't possible.

91.speaker: Havkelaag
91.text: New memberships are on hold for as long as those wretched Absolutists are banging on the city gates.

138.speaker: Havkelaag
138.text: It does, however, give you plenty of time to prepare your admission thesis. A brisk thirty-thousand words should be more than sufficient.

50.speaker: Player
50.text: I met one of your researchers in the Underdark. His name was Blurg.
50.context: NodeContext: Defensive, has heard this accusation before

3.speaker: Havkelaag
3.text: You don't say? Blurg happens to be upstairs, preparing a most unusual paper. I'm sure he'll be pleased to see a friendly face.

66.speaker: Player
66.text: I met two of your researchers in the Underdark - Blurg and Omeluum.
66.context: NodeContext: Defensive, has heard this accusation before

13.speaker: Havkelaag
13.text: A wonderful research partnership, I'm sure you'll agree. They are upstairs, if you wish to share any theories with them.

98.speaker: Player
98.text: 'The Society of Brilliance'? Looks like a library to me.
98.context: NodeContext: Defensive, has heard this accusation before

71.speaker: Havkelaag
71.text: I assure you, we are as well-provisioned an institution as any other you'll find in this city. We simply prefer to keep our wealth away from areas of study.
71.context: NodeContext: Defensive, has heard this accusation before

105.speaker: Havkelaag
105.text: One must stay humble in order to achieve true academic rigour.

38.speaker: Havkelaag
38.text: I say - that wasn't a githyanki egg you were fiddling around with, was it?
38.context: NodeContext: Curious, acting casual (he really wants the egg)

70.speaker: Havkelaag
70.text: How would you like to sell it to the Society of Brilliance? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

39.speaker: Havkelaag
39.text: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark.
39.context: NodeContext: Just saw the player destroy the githyanki egg he wanted. Cna't believe your stupidity

87.speaker: Havkelaag
87.text: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance.

59.speaker: Havkelaag
59.text: My thanks again for retrieving the specimen. It really is a perfect sample.
59.context: NodeContext: Just saw the player destroy the githyanki egg he wanted. Cna't believe your stupidity

60.speaker: Havkelaag
60.text: The Society's doors are always open to those who value knowledge and the proper application of it.
60.context: NodeContext: Just saw the player destroy the githyanki egg he wanted. Cna't believe your stupidity

64.speaker: Havkelaag
64.text: What are you playing at, destroying a perfectly good githyanki specimen like that? Utter foolishness.
64.context: NodeContext: Just saw the player destroy the githyanki egg he wanted. Cna't believe your stupidity

81.speaker: Havkelaag
81.text: Changed your mind, have you? The offer's still there - a fair price for the spawn, I'd say. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

95.speaker: Havkelaag
95.text: I knew you weren't Society material. I'll find another means of procuring an egg.

141.speaker: Havkelaag
141.text: Well met. What can the Society of Brilliance do for you?
